content:
It's understandable to find it difficult to reconcile the idea of eternal salvation with concepts of fairness and justice. Christianity, like any religion, has complex and varied beliefs about salvation and the nature of God's judgment.

In the case of forgiveness, Christianity teaches that through repentance, anyone can turn back to God regardless of past mistakes or wickedness. However, true repentance requires acknowledging the wrongdoing, seeking to make amends, and striving to change for the better. It's not simply a matter of saying a few words or asking for forgiveness without taking responsibility for one's actions.

Regarding salvation for non-Christians, some Christians believe that individuals who follow other religions or do not believe in Christianity can still achieve salvation if they lead a morally good life and seek to live according to God's will as they understand it. Others believe that salvation is only possible through faith in Jesus Christ.

Ultimately, the question of salvation and eternal damnation is a matter of personal belief and interpretation. It's important to seek out different perspectives and teachings, engage in critical thinking, and follow one's conscience when grappling with these complex issues.
